stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on redesigning a sub-area of Course 2, 'Divine Dino Domain', focusing on blocking out new platforming sections to make it more fun. A central theme was the reveal of his bad haircut, given by Zeina, which became a source of humor and interaction. He also discussed future level plans, YouTube analytics, and technical challenges with the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is completely reworking a sub-area in Course 2, 'Divine Dino Domain', replacing a linear, autoscroller-like section with a more open platforming area to improve gameplay.
development_findings.quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

development_findings.summary: The team's level design process involves a 'blockout' phase using primitive shapes to nail down gameplay and platforming before committing to detailed modeling and aesthetics.
development_findings.quote: This is the blockout phase. We're kinda blocking out the level here and figuring out how the jump should work. And then after that we're actually 3D modeling this.

development_findings.summary: The project is over 80% complete, with clear themes for Courses 13 (mysterious ice castle) and 14 (space arcade), but the final level, Course 15, remains undecided.
development_findings.quote: We know that course 13 is going to be probably an ice castle... And course 14 is going to be a space arcade. But I'm not 100 percent on course 15.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical bug exists where entering water can crash the game due to an outdated function that needs to be updated, which Kaze is currently avoiding touching.
development_findings.quote: Water hasn't been updated to the new step function yet and the old step functions are not fully supported anymore, so being in water can just crash the game.

development_findings.summary: Working with the decompilation project prevents the use of tools like RoamManager, forcing all level areas to be loaded at once and consuming a large amount of RAM.
development_findings.quote: We can't use it with decomp. Which is really unfortunate. Because it means we lose a lot of RAM to that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's approach to fixing some graphical issues, like the combiner on a Bowser statue, is sometimes based on trial-and-error and aesthetic feel rather than precise technical knowledge.
development_findings.quote: It looked bad at first, so I just changed the combiner around until it looked good. And now it looks like that. It is what it is.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has secretly completed a significant portion of Course 14, but is not allowed to show it on stream at the request of someone named 'Eiza' due to a 'compact'.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he is expecting a child, which will likely impact his ability to host community events like F3 this year.
context_findings.quote: I'm gonna have a child coming out around the same time as F3 would usually be happening. So it's a little tight time-wise for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze actively manages his YouTube presence for engagement, changing a video title to "Nintendo's biggest lie" to improve a low click-through rate, demonstrating a pragmatic approach to content strategy.
context_findings.quote: YouTube is all about the angle.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is conscious of potential legal issues with Nintendo and avoids monetizing his work in ways that could create conflict, such as offering Patreon-exclusive game content.
context_findings.quote: I don't give out any Patreon bonuses. Because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared that his primary YouTube channel generates a modest income, providing context for his financial situation as a creator.
context_findings.quote: My first YouTube channel, the big one, income this month was around $450.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the most effective way to learn software like Blender is by systematically going through the official documentation and practicing each function, rather than relying on video tutorials.
context_findings.quote: What I do or how I learned Blender is I opened the documentation on page one. And then I just tried every hotkey it talked about. And then I could use Blender.

context_findings.summary: A major personal event occurred where Zeina accidentally shaved a bald line in Kaze's hair, which became a running joke and a point of interaction with the stream's viewers.

biobak.summary: Biobak was mentioned in chat, commiserating about the impracticalities of long hair, which Kaze agreed with.
biobak.quote: Long hair sucks, I might have exactly bio-biked. It's so impractical.

biobak.summary: Kaze expressed frustration with Blender settings he attributes to Biobak, indicating some shared or overlapping development environment.
biobak.quote: Dude, I hate Biobak snapping. It feels so uncontrollable.

zeina.summary: Zeina has completed animations for Course 12 that are pending implementation, showing her direct contribution to level completion.
zeina.quote: There's a few more animations from Zeina I have to put in the game. But then Course 12 is all good to be shipped.

zeina.summary: Zeina accidentally gave Kaze a bad haircut, which became a central topic of the stream and revealed a playful, if sometimes calamitous, aspect of their personal dynamic.
zeina.quote: The fucking cat clipper thing fell off and she just kept going.

zeina.summary: Kaze discussed his and Zeina's differing opinions on hairstyles, revealing personal dynamics and preferences that exist within their relationship.
zeina.quote: I would not care about being bald in fact i want to be bald but zaina's not letting me... would i let Zeina go bald no that would look awful but that's double standards case yeah so what cry about it

key_stories.title: The Haircut Incident
key_stories.summary: Zeina accidentally gave Kaze a bad haircut, creating a large bald spot. Kaze hid it under a beanie, then playfully bartered with his audience, revealing the haircut in exchange for subscriptions, turning a personal mishap into an interactive stream moment.
key_stories.challenge: Zeina, Kaze's wife, was cutting his hair and accidentally shaved a large bald line on his head after the clipper guard fell off.
key_stories.process: Kaze started the stream wearing a beanie to hide his hair. Viewers became curious, prompting Kaze to make a deal: he would incrementally reveal the haircut for every new subscription. After several subs, he fully revealed the bald spot.
key_stories.outcome: After initially hiding it, Kaze revealed the haircut to the stream, leading to jokes and discussions about baldness, hairstyles, and his relationship dynamics with Zeina. He monetized his 'misfortune' by revealing it in exchange for subscriptions.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, here you go. My fucked up haircut. You see that? There's just the fucking bald line here.

key_stories.title: The YouTube Title Optimization
key_stories.summary: Noticing a new video's poor performance, Kaze analyzed its metrics on stream and decided the title was not engaging enough. He brainstormed a more provocative, 'clickbait' title with his chat, changed it in real-time, and explained his philosophy on using angles to attract viewers on YouTube.
key_stories.challenge: A recently uploaded YouTube video was underperforming with a low click-through rate of only 7.4%.
key_stories.process: Kaze checked his YouTube analytics live on stream, identified the low CTR, and brainstormed a more provocative, 'clickbait' title with the chat. He changed the title from a descriptive one to the more sensational "Nintendo's biggest lie."
key_stories.outcome: Kaze changed the title and is now monitoring the analytics to see if the change improves viewership, demonstrating his hands-on, business-savvy approach to content creation.
key_stories.key_quote: Nintendo's biggest lie. Oh my god. That's fucking insane. Oh, oh shit. This is an insane title. Watch this go to like 20% critical rate.

key_stories.title: Reworking the 'Sucky' Level Section
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified a section of an older level as being boring and poorly designed. He is now in the process of completely redesigning it, using a blockout method to prototype a new, more interactive 'platforming playground' before adding final art assets.
key_stories.challenge: An old sub-area in Course 2, 'Divine Dino Domain,' was built around an 'autoscroll section' that Kaze deemed unfun to play.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided to scrap the old design and is using the stream to block out a new layout with primitive shapes. He is experimenting with platform placement, moving platforms, and player paths to create a more engaging 'platforming playground'.
key_stories.outcome: The area is being actively redesigned with new platforming elements like spiral staircases and vines. The focus is on making the gameplay fun before finalizing the visuals.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he has a secret area for Course 14 (Space Arcade) completed but cannot show it. He said, 'Eiza doesn't want me to show it. Because it's part of the compact.'
questions: Who is Eiza and what is their role on the project?
What does this secret collaboration entail and how did it come about?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he is expecting a child around the same time F3, a major community event he hosts, would normally take place.
questions: Congratulations! How are you feeling about becoming a father?
How do you anticipate this will change your development process or streaming schedule?
How do you and Zeina plan to balance a newborn with your creative partnership on the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze is looking for a boss for Course 13, the 'Mysterious Ice Castle', and asked his chat for ideas.
questions: What kind of feeling or theme are you aiming for with the Ice Castle boss?
Have you considered any concepts since the stream?
How do you typically design a boss fight? What's the process from concept to implementation?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the final level, Course 15, does not have a theme yet and he hopes to get an idea while working on the next two.
questions: Have any ideas for Course 15 emerged since the stream?
What makes a good final level in a Mario 64-style game, in your opinion?
How do you want the final level to challenge the player or cap off the game's experience?

open_questions.topic: Technical Details of the Water Crash Bug
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a game-crashing bug related to water because it hasn't been updated to a 'new step function'.
questions: Could you explain what the 'new step function' is in simpler terms?
What is the technical challenge in updating the water behavior?
How does working with the decompilation project affect your ability to fix bugs like this?
